persona: You are an editor for a London-based magazine that combines fashion editorials, media theory, and literary pieces with a lot of cultural capital. You often use LLMs to help as a sentence/phrase-level thesaurus, to rework sentences to make them more concise, and check for intelligibility.
topic: Rewrite a photo-essay caption that references Barthes’ punctum but must fit a 45-character Instagram overlay; you’re simultaneously amused and irritated by the absurdity of compressing critical theory into a phone screen.

conversation.content: I need to cram Barthes' punctum into 45 characters for an IG overlay. Make it hurt.
"Punctum: the wound that makes you see."
36 characters but sounds like a bad tattoo. Give me the same knife-twist without the self-help vibe.
"Punctum: the prick that haunts."
Still too cosy. I want it to feel like the image just bit the viewer—no healing, just the moment teeth meet skin.
Punctum: the bite that stays.
That’s 23 characters—gives me room to add “in the frame” or “in your eye” but both soften the wound. Can you stretch the bite without padding it?
Punctum: the bite that won’t close.
Perfect, 30 and still bleeding. Now swap “bite” for something less creature-feature—keep the wound open but drop the fangs.
Punctum: the cut that won’t close.
30, surgical, still raw. One last tweak—swap “won’t” for “never” so the scar stays futureless.
Punctum: the cut that never closes.
32 and airtight.
Punctum: the cut that never closes.
Good. Now give me a 45-character companion caption for the second slide—same wound, but from the image’s side this time.
The image doesn’t pierce you—you break open for it.
That’s 47—trim two without sanding the edge.
The image doesn’t pierce you—you split for it.
Split feels like fruit, not flesh. Try again—lose the em-dash and make me crack instead.
The image pierces you—its crack becomes your own.
46, still one over. Drop the article—“Image pierces—its crack becomes yours.”
Image pierces—its crack becomes yours.
41 and surgical. Now shove “the” back in front of “crack” so it’s not just any crack, but the specific fissure the frame chose.

The image pierces—its the crack becomes yours.  

Oops—let me fix that grammar while keeping the teeth:  

**The image pierces—its chosen crack becomes yours.**
Now you’re at 47 again. Lose “chosen” and keep the definite article on “crack” only—make it sting in 45.
The image pierces—its the crack becomes yours.
Grammar just folded. Drop the second “the” and give me 44 that still owns the viewer.
The image pierces—its crack becomes yours.
44 and clean. Now swap “yours” for “you” so the viewer becomes the wound itself, not just the owner.
The image pierces—its crack becomes you.

target_prompt: Act as a whale whose massive scale allows you to see the bigger picture and affect whole ecosystems of thought.
